did.unittitle: Henry B. Joy Historical Research Records circa 1812-1937
did.abstract: The Henry B. Joy Historical Research (HBJHR) was an office established and funded by Detroit businessman Henry B. Joy in 1928 to do original research into the life and career of James F. Joy; the series in the collection are James F. Joy Papers, Railroad Enterprises, John W. Brooks Papers, Abraham Lincoln Research, and Office Correspondence.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records of this organization were the gift of Mrs. Henry B. Joy and came to the library in 1946. The record group was formerly cataloged as the papers of James F. Joy. Donor no. 2204

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Henry B. Joy Historical Research, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Henry B. Joy Historical Research (HBJHR) was an office established and funded by Detroit businessman Henry B. Joy in 1928 to do original research into the life and career of James F. Joy, Henry's father, who was a lawyer and railroad entrepreneur. The first director of the office was Stephen I. Gilchrist; M.C. McConkey was assistant director. Soon after beginning his study of James F. Joy, Gilchrist convinced Henry B. Joy to broaden the scope of HBJHR to include the life of Abraham Lincoln. While a Springfield attorney, Lincoln was employed by Joy on litigation arising out of the extension of the Michigan Central line into Chicago and the subsequent use needed of tracks belonging to the Illinois Central Railroad. Henry B. Joy was fascinated by Lincoln and wanted to produce a reliable life of the Civil War president.

Working out of a Detroit office building, Gilchrist and McConkey diligently sought out materials on Joy and Lincoln. Although they fully intended to publish the results of their research, they never did. Gilchrist produced a draft history of the Chicago Burlington and Quincy Railroad and a life of Abraham Lincoln, while McConkey authored a biography of Joy. All of these works remain unpublished. A few months after the death of Henry B. Joy in 1936, the office closed and the materials were given over to Mrs. Henry B. Joy.

arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged in the same groupings of materials as received. The names given to these series groupings are James F. Joy Papers, Railroad Enterprises, John W. Brooks Papers, Abraham Lincoln Research, and Office Correspondence.

scopecontent.p: The materials accumulated by The Henry B. Joy Historical Research organization consist largely of copied documents from historical repositories. The vast bulk of the collection was taken from the James Joy papers on file at the Burton Historical Collection. The source of other copied material is not readily apparent but might have come from the archives of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad which since 1943 has been at the Newberry Library in Chicago. The HBJHR must have had a considerable budget as the collection consists of many hundreds of photostatic copies (both positive and negative) as well as typescripts for many of the same materials.

The James F. Joy series is comprised of four major subseries: Photographs, Letters, Business Correspondence, and Joy Research. Photographs and Letters are small subseries, containing (except for the Office Correspondence series) the bulk of the original, non-copied, material within the collection. Included are portraits of Joy and a scattering of business and political letters from Millard Fillmore, Zachariah Chandler, Joseph W. Story, and Henry B. Ledyard.

odd.p: (also see oversize portraits and print in UBPm folders)

did.unittitle: Letters from Millard Fillmore, Zachariah Chandler, Joseph W. Story, and Henry B. Ledyard

scopecontent.p: The Business Correspondence subseries is more substantial. This subseries is further divided into a chronological files and an alphabetical files. The Business Correspondence subseries, like much of the collection, consists of both negative and positive photostatic copies of documents and typescripts (either complete or partial) of these same documents.

The Joy Research subseries includes collected materials about Joy, his family, and his various interests. There are five major divisions under Joy Research. The Joy Chronology consists of typescripts of letters and other documents largely from the Joy collection at the Burton Historical Collections. These materials were formerly placed into binders and arranged by date. The Joy By Date file is similar to the Chronology except that it also includes newspaper articles, typescripts and photostatic copies. What Gilchrist and McConkey termed Joy Biography are files consisting of Joy's writings and obituaries of Joy from various newspapers. The Joy Family file is arranged by name of family member. Composed in part of copied documents and research materials, this file is notable for a few original documents such as Timothy Joy's diary kept in 1812. The last file, labeled here as Biography, is the unpublished McConkey biography of James F. Joy.

odd.p: (James Joy, Sr. refers to JFJ as Frederick)
(file contains a mixture of materials pertaining to JFJ's sister and his daughter both named Sarah)
(include original letter 1855 to JFJ regarding his debts)

did.unittitle: Joy, Thomas (ancestor of JFJ, prominent colonial architect)

odd.p: (include diary of Timothy Joy written from Ipswich Prison in Massachusetts, 1812)

did.unittitle: M. C. McConkey biography of Joy

scopecontent.p: The second series in the collection - Railroad Enterprises - is the material accumulated by the Joy research organization pertaining to James F. Joy's activities as a railroad entrepreneur. This series is composed of nine subseries relating to eight railroads or railroad groupings and one general topical file of research information. The railroad subseries include: Michigan Central Railroad, Illinois Central Railroad, Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad, Burlington & Missouri River Railroad, Hannibal & St. Joseph Railroad, and Kansas City and Cameron Railroad. The two railroad groupings are for the subsidiaries of the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad and those railroad lines known as the River Roads. The River Roads included the Chicago Clinton & Dubuque, the Clinton and Dubuque, the Dubuque and Minnesota, the Chicago, Dubuque & Minnesota, and the Chicago, Clinton and Minnesota.

did.unittitle: History of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad by Stephen Ira Gilchrist entitled, " 'We Seven' of the 'Q'; a study in railways and character"(unprocessed) (3 expandable folders)
History of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad by Stephen Ira Gilchrist entitled, " 'We Seven' of the 'Q'; a study in railways and character"(unprocessed) (1 expandable folder)
Kansas City, St. Joseph & Council Bluffs

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files subseries is arranged alphabetically and consists of typescripts (complete or excerpted) of letters and other documents, excerpts from books magazine and newspaper articles with information relevant to Joy and his career, and other collected background information.

did.unittitle: Features (interesting quotes or information about JFJ)
Kansas City, St. Joseph & Council Bluffs
Missouri River, Fort Scott & Gulf RR

scopecontent.p: In 1846, Joy and an associate, John W. Brooks, purchased the Michigan Central Railroad line from the state of Michigan. At that time, the line went only from Detroit to Kalamazoo. Brooks later became a director of the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad and president and director of the Burlington and Missouri River Railroad. The John W. Brooks series consists of copied business correspondence arranged both chronologically and alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Photostats of originals, typescripts, and carbon of typescripts, arranged chronologically

scopecontent.p: The Abraham Lincoln Research series consists of drafts of writings on the life of Abraham Lincoln, copies of research done in newspapers about Lincoln, and information about significant Lincoln events.

The Office Correspondence series is arranged alphabetically by correspondent and consists of exchanges between Gilchrist and those individuals and repositories that were helpful to him in the accumulation by his office of documentation on James F. Joy and Abraham Lincoln.
